{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3624884,"name":"Dan_Karol","username":"Dan_Karol","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dan_karol/{size}/227378_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T01:52:48.991Z","cooked":"

A friend just showed me his new bike and I was astounded to see the belts and pulleys used for power transmission. The belt features a groove through the middle that engages a tab between the teeth of the pulley. This example appears to be an 8mm pitch.

This has a few enhancements over existing belts and pulleys:

  1. The pulley can be machined from billet without swaging or pressing flanges
  2. The belt will track the centerline perfectly eliminating the need excess width.

My understanding is that these belts are available from Gates

Bike 11920×2560 361 KB

Bike 21920×1440 237 KB

The biggest downside that I can see is that the central groove can’t be oversized making this a bad choice for an intake that can have lots of deformation.

agree those look good and light, and the belts are very strong, but I think the range of belt lengths available is very limited, and long – bike sized.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-05-15T02:20:24.942Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":291,"readers_count":290,"score":58.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":501767,"topic_slug":"center-flange-pulleys-and-grooved-belts","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/center-flange-pulleys-and-grooved-belts/501767/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3624945,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T03:38:14.432Z","cooked":"
Dan_Karol:

My understanding is that these belts are available from Gates

gates.com

Carbon Drive Bicycle Belts | Gates Corporation

Gates Poly Chain synchronous belts help reduce maintenance, component cost and weight, withstand rust and chemicals, and achieve energy savings when replacing V-belts or older synchronous belts. Find your industrial or automotive synchronous belt to...

Unfortunately gates haven’t posted specifications documents for these yet, they are not designed for use in high-shock enviroments like FRC.

Dan_Karol:

The biggest downside that I can see is that the central groove can’t be oversized making this a bad choice for an intake that can have lots of deformation.

There are ways to design around this. You don’t need everything on the intake to be flexible, you only need flexibility in the right places to ensure the intake collapses on intake and moves out of the way on side hits. Placing rigid plates between pulleys while keeping the rest flexible does this while avoiding issues due to changing C2C.

I’m sure it wouldn’t be too hard to modify existing HTD belts with a central slot. A rotary tool in a fixture with a fence or channel for the belt is all you would need.

Thanks for the link!

Alex_Y:

they are not designed for use in high-shock enviroments like FRC.

Many applications of belts for FRC are not “high-shock”. And I would think if anything the carbon fiber tensile cords would make these belts stronger than the fiberglass tensile cord belts typically used in FRC.

The biggest issue is as of now these belts seem like a product designed for a rather limited market of bicycle power trains, and so as said above the size options (in both pitch and length) are limited and not right for FRC.

Here’s another link: Bikes - Gates Carbon Drive™ System for Bicycles | Gates Carbon Drive™
